citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, there was an insufficient number of readily identifiable employees monitoring public members
interacting with animals or areas of animal interaction. One vehicle was followed through the drive through safari with no
attendant monitoring the feeding interactions occurring from a member of the public’s car (observed feeding zebras,
llamas, alpacas, an eland, and camels). A tractor driven by an employee with an attached trailer was observed taking a
group of children through the safari. The employee would stop occasionally to allow feeding of the animals and the
employee would step down off the tractor to monitor one side of the trailer, but children were also feeding animals on the
opposite side of the trailer unobserved. In the budgie aviary, one attendant was present while members of the public were
feeding the birds but instead of monitoring the interactions, the attendant was looking away and/or at their phone instead
of monitoring the interactions. At one point the attendant left for a break while members of the public were still present in
the aviary for approximately 10 minutes, so the public was left unattended while feeding the birds. At the giraffe feeding
station and the farm animal petting area, adults and children were observed feeding the giraffe and farm animals with no
readily identifiable attendant present. Lack of employee oversight of direct interactions between the animals and the
visitors may lead to injury to the humans and/or injury or distress to the animals. A responsible, knowledgeable, and
readily identifiable employee or attendant must be present at all times during periods of public contact.
Correct by JUNE 30, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
STEPHANIE MAYARD, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.131(d)(2) 
   
Handling of animals. 
At the time of inspection, there was an insufficient number of readily identifiable employees monitoring public members 
interacting with animals or areas of animal interaction. One vehicle was followed through the drive through safari with no 
attendant monitoring the feeding interactions occurring from a member of the public’s car (observed feeding zebras, 
llamas, alpacas, an eland, and camels). A tractor driven by an employee with an attached trailer was observed taking a 
group of children through the safari. The employee would stop occasionally to allow feeding of the animals and the 
employee would step down off the tractor to monitor one side of the trailer, but children were also feeding animals on the 
opposite side of the trailer unobserved. In the budgie aviary, one attendant was present while members of the public were 
feeding the birds but instead of monitoring the interactions, the attendant was looking away and/or at their phone instead 
of monitoring the interactions. At one point the attendant left for a break while members of the public were still present in 
the aviary for approximately 10 minutes, so the public was left unattended while feeding the birds. At the giraffe feeding 
station and the farm animal petting area, adults and children were observed feeding the giraffe and farm animals with no 
readily identifiable attendant present. Lack of employee oversight of direct interactions between the animals and the 
visitors may lead to injury to the humans and/or injury or distress to the animals. A responsible, knowledgeable, and 
readily identifiable employee or attendant must be present at all times during periods of public contact.  
Correct by JUNE 30, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
STEPHANIE MAYARD, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
